B000E6UK5K|4.0|\\"On An Island\\" features the type of music that Pink Floyd and David Gilmour fans have come to expect from the man--there's lots of moody, atmospheric playing, Gilmour's memorable raspy vocals and some of the best material he's written in years. Collaborating with guitarist/songwriter Phil Manzanera of Roxy Music and veteran producer Chris Thomas (The Pretenders), Gilmour has crafted an atmospheric album full of hazy instrumentals and songs that may not rock out the way fans are used to but are still filled with passion and emotion. By the way, if you decide not to buy this locally some retail outlets are offering a bonus disc that includes an additional song. How does this compare to his other solo albums? Well each one represented a different decade in Gilmour's life so they are all quite different and difficult to compare but the quality of the songwriting is top notch here as on those. This effort is a little more focused than his first (\\"David Gilmour\\") and a little less commercial than his second (\\"About Face\\").<br /><br />Written solo and in collaboration with Polly Samson (a journalist and writer who wrote some of the lyrics for \\"The Division Bell\\" as well as Mrs. Gilmour)providing words on most of the tracks \\"On An Island\\" features a wide variety of memorable guest players (Floyd's Richard Wright, David Crosby & Graham Nash on backing vocals, Jools Holland formerly of Squeeze, Robert Wyatt and--surprisingly--guitarist Phil Manzanera playing keyboards). I'll be the first to admit that Samson isn't Waters as a lyricist but her words are servicable for the songs and occasionally inspired (hence the four stars and not five). The production by Gilmour, Manzanera and Thomas is atmospheric providing the perfect sonic backdrop for Gilmour to do what he does best--play and sing.<br /><br />\\"On An Island\\" does allows Gilmour to experiment a bit as well with the material but what's most interesting as how emotionally direct the songs are. Clearly no man's an island and that's true of Gilmour as well--he works well with his collaborators building a sonic home on this solo album. The album does have flaws for example the pacing is a bit turgid at times and truly it would have helped to have a solid hard rock number here to break through the haze on the album but overall it's a terrific effort and a worthy follow up to his work leading Floyd and solo efforts. It's a shame we had to wait for so long Gilmour to assert himself on record again but it was well worth the wait. David, don't make us wait another decad! Oh, by the way, happy birthday!Gilmour as well--he works well with his collaborators building a sonic home on this solo album. B000BM3ZUE|5.0|For those who aren't familiar, this album is GG's second, and the last of their Crimso-influenced prog period--with \\"serious\\" lyrics, mellotrons, classical themes, etc.  It wasn't until the next album that the band began to find its unique polyphonic groove--a process that achieved fruition on the fourth album, \\"Octopus\\", with the arrival of John Weathers on drums. <br /> <br />As a died-in-the-wool GG fanatic, I always devalued this album a bit--the drummer, and the music, is rather ponderous relative to the \\"serious fun\\" they generated in later releases, and its chromatic textures have always sounded a little \\"gray\\" to me.  However, their allusions to 20th century music (like Schoenberg, Webern, and Bartok) were a refreshing contrast to the classical and romantic references of most other prog bands, and admittedly it is a VERY adventurous album, even for Gentle Giant.  <br /> <br />However, this remaster has awakened me to the beauty of this music.  Rather than applying contemporary pop remastering techniques as many reissues do, Repertoire has reapproached this music with a subtle reverent hand appropriate for classical music, with outstanding results.  The \\"gray\\" in the music has turned to pastel shades, and the delicacy of the original production is evident as never before.  Tracks that I didn't appreciate earlier--such as the mystical, dissonant tone poems \\"Edge of Twilight\\" and \\"The Moon Is Down\\"--are now revealed in all their fragile detail.  It is a flat out lovely job of remastering, and the end product is a definitive version that fills a gap in both my CD collection, and in my appreciation of this marvelous band. <br /> <br />It may not be my absolute favorite of their records, but it is truely unlike any album done by this band or any other that I know of.  If you've always loved this album, then you must have it.  If you love this band, but like me never appreciated this album fully, you probably should too.  Simply put, it is progressive music that truely lives up to that label, and sounds as unique and daring as it did then.    <br />  <br />

078324228X|2.0|The first thing you should know about The Hurricane is that it was based on two books, one of which (The Sixteenth Round) was written by Rubin Carter. <br /> <br />The second thing you should know is that Rubin Carter is not a man of exemplary honesty. <br /> <br />The third thing you should know is that the other book (Lazarus and the Hurricane) on which this movie was based was written by two of the Canadians who bought into Carter's hokum, as have so many after them. <br /> <br />I will not go into a point-by-point list of the patently false claims that Carter makes in his book, since other posters here have already done a good job of that. Instead, I'd like to offer some reactions to those here who have given this movie glowing reviews. These are divided into three groups. <br /> <br />The first is composed of those who did not know they were taken for a ride. If you belong in this group, I do not fault you. Hollywood has a way of perpetrating some very repugnant deceptions on the unsuspecting public. But let me ask you this: if you were presented with hard evidence that this movie is just one big lie put forward by the title \\"hero,\\" would you still rate it highly? <br /> <br />If your answer is \\"yes,\\" then you belong in the second group, those who gave this movie a thumbs-up on the basis of its being a powerfully moving drama, and never mind the glaring factual inaccuracies. To this group, I have this to say: if a filmmaker wants to present a true-life story, he has a responsibility to see to it that he has his facts right. It's called integrity, and it means placing truthfulness far above profitability. You say this is a dramatization and not a documentary? Well, even a dramatization should be done with some integrity. I can go along with some minor embellishments here and there, but when a movie is based on a series of disgustingly blatant lies and tries to pass itself off as a true story, that, in my book, is unforgivable. And so what if it was a rival studio that went out of its way to expose this movie's dishonesty? Vested interest does not render their arguments invalid. <br /> <br />Finally, to the third group, those who actually believe that Carter is in fact a martyr-scholar, I ask you to please open your eyes. There is absolutely no documentation to support Carter's claims that he defended his friend from a pedophile, that he was a civil rights activist, that he was robbed of a crucial ring victory, and so many other proclamations aimed at propping up his hero image. On the other hand, there are reams of documents that present virtually irrefutable evidence that these very proclamations are a product of one man's delusional fantasies. You say that Cal Deal, the man behind graphicwitness.com, is a racist? Please visit graphicwitness.com /carter/racism.html. Also, know this: Deal went into the Rubin Carter case actually believing that Carter was innocent. It took just one interview for Deal to see the many glaring inconsistencies in Carter's statements. He went on to uncover numerous documents and testimonies that exposed Carter as a liar. <br /> <br />Many accounts today have it that Carter is a changed man. I sincerely hope this is a real change, and not just a show. But whatever the case, the fact remains that he owes it to the public to admit that his book and this movie are just a lot of hogwash.  <br /> <br />I'm not counting on that, though.
B00097A5I6|1.0|For much of the 90's Oasis was my favorite band.  I saw them live from the early Tony MCCarroll on drums days through this summer.  WTSMG is one of the best CD's of all time and I personally like Definitely Maybe even better.  I devoured their singles and excused the hiccup that was Be Here Now. <br /> <br />A few years ago Oasis released their 4th record Standing on the Shoulder of Giants.  Outstanding CD but panned by many.  It was sometime during this period that original members Bonehead and Quigsy left the band.  I think it was also the period where Noel cleaned up his act. <br /> <br />Unfortunately the 5th Album Heathen Chemistry was poor and now Oasis has hit rock bottom.  This CD is just brutal - no fire, no passion, just sounds like a bunch of guys going through the motions.  The only track that even sounds like old Oasis is A Bell Will Ring. <br /> <br />Liam Gallagher did not take care of his voice - if you do not believe me listen to the early recordings - he sang back then. Whether it is books, movies, or video games, if it involves zombies in any way, you can bet I own it.  Therefore, everything that Max Brooks fits into his guide to surviving a world filled with the undead is something that I could truly appreciate and smile at.  I never really laughed out loud, though.  I guess that the only reason that I found this book in the humor sections is because there is really no other section to place it in.  For any reader who just picks it up because it sounds interesting, I doubt that they will be happy with the result.  For anyone who is a George Romero fan, though, will love this book.  Reading this book made we want to watch the Living Dead films all over again, right in a row.  I don't know if Max Brooks was just trying to be funny, or if he actually appreciates the zombie genre, but his book fits in perfectly with everything you've seen on film before, and expands on it to an insane degree.  The best part of the book is how seriously it takes itself.  I'm sure it could have been a lot funnier if Brooks didn't write the book like we were actually living in an undead world as he wrote it.  The book is completely serious about itself, and, therefore, it is really only funny in the ironic sense.

B000E6UK5K|4.0|After years of bitterness over Roger Waters' unilateral decision to disband Pink Floyd -- reflected in the lyrics of post-Waters Floyd -- it sounds like David has finally made peace with it.  Now content to \\"go it alone,\\" a human island as it were, he is making a trial escape from the pressures and expectations of legions of rabid PF fans.<br /><br />Consequently this album is distinctly unFloydlike.  Oh sure, his guitar and voice will always recall PF since he was so much a foundation of their sound -- but on \\"Island\\" the song structures are of a different scale from the grand anthems of PF.  These songs are smaller, simpler, more rural, more of a personal scale, sounding maybe even like they were written and performed on a houseboat.  It's a less-ambitious undertaking.<br /><br />I'm not even sure \\"more personal\\" is accurate -- he says Polly Sampson wrote all the lyrics, which are entirely emotionally neutral: observational, almost meaningless word images.<br /><br />\\"More personal\\" perhaps in the sense that he is finally freed from the past, released from bitterness, free to create music of his own choice for the first time in a long time.  His relief and comfort are palpable.<br /><br />And also the reason for only four stars.  After 22 years since his last solo album -- and 12 since the last PF collaboration -- you'd think he'd have a folio of stronger songs than these.  These all feel like 'B' songs which didn't make the cut for earlier albums.  If you imagine them without the singing and soaring guitar leads, there's not much left.<br /><br />It's almost as if he's daring you to compare him to PF, as Lennon did after washing his hands of the Beatles.

0316172324|4.0|According to Gladwell, we think without thinking by  using limited information to come to our conclusion. This is an approach we use in the time of information overload, probably do reduce the intelectual stress of the overload.      Rapid cognition is a different name for hunch or intuition and several of the examples Gladwell discusses are interesting:  the discovery of a Greek statue that fooled one group of art experts, but was later shown to be a fake by another group. Based on this example, the book analyzes alternative uses of thinslicing and gives a wide range of example from speed dating, tennis, war games, malpractice suits, popular music, and predicting divorce.  The stories are interesting and Gladwell expertly weaves these examples with accounts of scientific studies.  He points out an important fact: science partially, but seldom full, explains the largely unconscious phenomenon that we have all experienced at one time or another in our lives.     I agree with many reviewers that thinslicing reflects our experiences, training, knowledge and prejudices.    This book is probably one of the more thoughtprovoking books that I have read.  He writes well and the text is engaging.  Recommended.

His lyrics are nice and even though he can go to the trash that everybody else raps about he actually talks about something different every once in a while. The problem would be the fact that there are way too many skits. The skits are weak and you start to lose track of the songs. B00005JOFO|5.0|The various reactions I've heard and read about Brokeback Mountain seem to say more about the reactor than it does the film.  A very simple film about two very specific characters in a very specific time and place has been exaggerated into all sorts of politicized nonsense for and against.  So many agendas, so little time. <br /> <br />I found this a beautifully written, acted, directed and photographed film filled with subtlety and understanding.  A compassionate study of an illicit love in a time and place of great repression, the movie walked a knife-edge and would have been even greater fodder for the late-night comedians had it not been in the hands of superb film-makers. Their skill has allowed a general audience to appreciate a film containing, for many, uncomfortable subject matter. <br /> <br />I applaud the great courage of the two young leads who have been justly praised for their performances.  It looks good now, but it had a tremendous possibility for not only failure but also humiliation, and I recognize their risk-taking. <br /> <br />But there was the writing of McMurtry and Osana, and the direction of Ang Lee and they made it work. And the specificity of the time and place is everything. <br /> <br />This is a story of these two men, and the ruin they bring to themselves and others trying to live their lives as a lie, which was about their only option there and then.  I don't believe these guys lives bear any relation to the lives of gays in the great urban settings of New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles etc.  Jack might have fit in there, Ennis...never.  <br /> <br />I enjoyed the film as a specific story, like any other story.  The great craft involved allowed me to accept these characters and to eventually care about them, but I found no need to extrapolate beyond that to any great generalities.  If there was a message to this film, to me it was simply: live and let live.  And my God, wouldn't that be something. <br />

B000E6UK5K|5.0|There are two camps of Pink Floyd fans, and you really had no choice about which one you belonged to: you either discovered them with, or after, \\"Dark Side of the Moon\\", or you somehow caught on to them before that career-turner. I first heard them, oddly enough, with the excellent \\"Obscured by clouds\\", and then went back to everything previous, all before \\"Dark Side\\" was ever released. If you were an early Floyd fan like that, I think you came to expect one thing with them: the unexpected. Some material worked (Astronomy Domine, One of these days, Careful with that Axe, Cymbaline, etc. etc. etc.), and some songs didn't work (Seamus, Corporal Clegg and several parts of Atom Heart Mother), but you got what you got, and we all hung patiently, waiting for every subsequent album. Post Dark-Siders, on the other hand, expect a masterpiece from beginning to end with every album. So it is with David's new album. Not perfect, but very much him, and very rewarding from beginning to end for those willing to sit and listen to it with an open mind. Too mellow? Do we not remember the earliest of Floyd days, with acoustic-based songs like A Pillow of Winds, Green is the Colour or Remember a Day, the likes of which show up on this album in the form of The Blue or Then I Close My Eyes? I, for one, am A.) thrilled that Dave came out of retirement, and B.) very pleased that there is nothing resembing \\"Division Bell\\" AOR junk like Lost For Words or Take It Back. On top of all that, the guitar playing is, as always, masterful and eloquent, emotional and liquid. So, forget your expectations - David Gilmour and Pink Floyd have NEVER been about expectations.

0060512806|5.0|\\"Cryptonomicon,\\" like much of Neal Stephenson's work, defies easy description.  His ideas are so involved and interwoven with the text, it can be difficult to unravel the story as a whole.  \\"Cryptonomicon\\" deals with the ideas of codebreaking, information security, Holocaust morality, global economics, the evolution of mythology, and the inherent insanity of war.  He includes complex descriptions of encryption schemes and expositions of many complicated ideas, yet somehow manages to maintain a slick narrative. <br /> <br />I really cannot praise Stephenson's literary genius enough.  Having read five of his books now (\\"Cryptonomicon,\\" the Baroque Cycle, and \\"Snow Crash\\") I feel that \\"Cryptonomicon\\" is second only to \\"Snow Crash,\\" and vastly superior to many books I have read.  He manages his multiple-perspective narrative skillfully and creates fascinating characters in a wholly believable world.
B000AP2ZDK|4.0|J Dilla a.k.a. Jay Dee passed away Friday, February 10, 2006 from complications from lupus.  I started the review off this way because a lot of people don't know a lot about Jay Dee.  Unless you were heavily in tune with the hip-hop scene, you may not have noticed his presence.  As an early member of Slum Village, Jay Dee was instrumental in bringing older R&B and Jazz sound back to the forefront of hip-hop music.  It has always been present in rap music, dating back to \\"Rapper's Delight\\" by the Sugarhill Gang.  It's been continured over the years by deejays like Pete Rock, Jazzy Jeff, Dj Premier, and most notably Kanye West.  Jay Dee continued this tradition in all the music he has produced for the likes of A Tribe Called Quest, Slum Village, Pharcyde, and Common.  Donuts is his last release before his untimely death and serves up some of the best instrumental music to rock your head to.<br /><br />It's virtually impossible for this to be like other reviews where you break down each track.  Each track possesses it's own unique flavor.  And even though there are some that will leave you perplexed, it still shows you the extensive amount of time it must take to find those tracks that make the cut.  Jay Dee obviously did a lot of digging in the crates for some of these cuts.  Still other selections are a blending of sounds and samples, almost putting you in the mind of techno or drum-n-bass music.<br /><br />Those that appreciate the time and energy it takes to be a deejay and producer will be enlightened from the collection on Donuts.  If anything, Donuts will serve as the starting point and inspiration for the growing number of deejays and wannabe producers in the game today.  Jay Dee's respect in the game didn't come over night, but he never let go of niche once he found his place in the industry.  He will be truly missed by those who know of him personally, those who knew of his work, and those who will come to know his music over the years to come.  Be on the lookout for a future Jay Dee album from BBE this summer.  R.I.P. Jay Dee.he lookout for a future Jay Dee album from BBE this summer.  R.I.P. Jay Dee.

B00000G3I2|3.0|I saw The Big Chill for the first time only this year. It was playing on TNT or some such station and I was intrigued. I've since purchased the DVD and have enjoyed the film several times now. In my view, it deserves to be considered a minor cult classic. <br /> <br />What I found was a collection of very good efforts by actors who were, at the time, not well known and fairly inexperienced. I'm quite impressed by Mr Kasdan's eye for casting. This is a superb ensemble! We find in this story a re-grouping of a previously tightly-bonded klatch with the usual variety of contrasting personalities and yet a melding of similar interests. <br />  <br />Alex dies and thus the reason for the gathering. At the funeral (Chapter 2), Alex does not seem to have very many friends. Outside of a handful of family members, Alex' few former classmates and his youngish girlfriend, the church is empty. Even the minister didn't really know him. <br /> <br />These friends end up staying with Sarah (Glenn Close) and her husband Harold (Kevin Kline) over the longish weekend. They spout off glib one-liners and exchange a somewhat forced repartee in multiple attempts to lighten their grief. How many of us have done the same thing in our own moments of despair? <br /> <br />I was impressed by the frequent and liberal use of the word `love.' Several times by word and by gesture, these people affirm their deep commitment to each other. Several exchanges (some heated, some more Socratic) ensue that reflect both unresolved issues from a previous life and the current grieving process. The obvious attachments and subsequent fulfillment of sexual tensions seems to include a nod toward our collective Survival Instinct. It's at once ironic and terribly humorous that the person most openly interested in The Act (Jeff Goldblum as Michael) is left to play with the propeller on his junior aviator's bed.  <br />Moral considerations aside, I somehow did find satisfaction in Sarah's making arrangements (Chapters 25-27) for Harold to attempt to father Meg's (Mary Kay Place) child. Perhaps this was self-induced pay-back for former sins to a degree, but I also found it to be a selfless act on the behalf of a good friend - well, maybe two good friends. Harold didn't seem to mind.   <br /> <br />I suppose the popular front-runners in this movie could be Glenn Close and William Hurt. For my money, I'll take Mary Kay Place. She's solid and she wears comfortably into middle age (episodes of Law and Order, The West Wing and Numb3rs most recently). <br /> <br />In writing book and film reviews for Amazon, I tend to do a little research. Including in that is a reading of at least a portion of the reviews previously posted. The Big Chill seems to have pulled in an inordinate number of reviews not only negative but often angry, and for a curious set of reasons: \\"the sets are cheap, the acting is dated and the conversation shallow.\\" I don't agree. <br /> <br />This is a \\"Conversational Film,\\" a true \\"Talkie,\\" a film where the substance of history and idea and thought is delivered much more so by verbal interactions among the characters than by elaborate sets or expensive action sequences. It's a Time Capsule depicting a narrow segment of Collegiate Society. It could have just as easily been a group of Pre-Nursing Students, or a Bible Study/Buddhist Meditation/Holocaust Studies Group or just some Kids interested in Agri-Business. Mr Kasdan chose some young Radical Anarchist Wantabes who decided that some attempt at conformation was necessary in order to get along in The Cold World. Not all are pleased about it. One or two tried to be more faithful to the Ideal than the others but it was a costly choice: one becoming an almost constant user of recreational pharmaceuticals and the other becoming dead. <br /> <br />Neither am I bothered so much by the `missing flashback.' Mr Kasdan made an editorial decision with which I happen to agree. I find amusement in knowing that the exposed body parts (sans the face), whilst being prepared and included in the final version, belongs to Kevin Costner. It fits in with the black humor of it all, almost on the same level as someone auditioning for the part of Yorick in Hamlet. <br /> <br />There is wonderful nostalgia in this film! Why should we expect such a work, 23 years old, to align with current thinking? Why should we expect it to reflect the impatient and shallow Gen-X World or some middle-aged shriveled prune-head (me included) who can't or simply won't make allowances for others. We should relax a little and view it and enjoy it within the context of its own Time. <br /> <br />I for one would be delighted to see some of my college friends again; it's been 30-plus years. And if I should do so well as these guys, who so obviously love and care for each other, I'd consider it time and money and effort well spent. <br /> <br />But most of us would have had to have been there, I suppose. <br /> <br />Russell de Ville <br />8 March 2006 <br /> <br />

B00000JNO1|5.0|Skynyrd did something very early on in their career that very few bands do. They released an AMAZING first album, and then followed it with a just as equally AMAZING second album (Pronounced, and Second Helping respectively.) With these two records the southern Skynyrd boys could have called it quits and still went down as legends, but fortunately MCA demanded more records.<br />Skynyrds third album NUTHIN FANCY, is not the absolute triumph that the first two albums were (perhaps the band recognized this when giving it the title?) but it ain't no waste of resource either.<br />It was 1975, and rock music was generally getting to be louder and louder all around. Hard rock bands were taking ques from the metal pioneers and cranking up the sound. This can easily be noticed on the opening track SATURDAY NIGHT SPECIAL and the albums first single ON THE HUNT. These songs lose a little of the heart felt personalities of the first records but are both completely pisser, and kept the band well seated at the front of the seventies Hard Rock board.<br />The rest of the album takes on a more down home southern style, than even the first two. Closer to an Allman Brothers feel than a Skynyrd feel, but again, this is not a bad thing. The bluesy ballad CHEATIN WOMAN is memorable, as is the moving, tonky, WHISKEY- ROCK-A-ROLLER. Other goods on this plate as well.<br />Some may say that this is nothing but an album of filler SKYNYRD stuff, but I can't agree with that. This is great stuff, just not as legendary as what preceeded it. Its classic rock music, from a classic rock band, its just that it prides itself in bein' NUTHIN FANCY.<br />I gave this one four and three fourth stars... but we can just say I gave it five.

B0000AQS0F|5.0|Once upon a time, I found the Firefly DVD set, and, armed with a gift card, a great deal of curiosity, and faith in Whedon's brilliance, I snatched it up.  I popped the first DVD into my computer, and hoping that I hadn't wasted my money, I watched the pilot episode.   <br /> <br />I didn't sleep at all that night, and I'd finished all fourteen episodes by the end of the next day.  I sat stunned after Objects in Space, wondering what kind of idiot would cancel a show so wonderful.  I honestly love it more than both Buffy and Angel combined, something I'd never have thought possible.  Firefly has even usurped Stargate's position as my favorite Sci-Fi show. <br /> <br />The visual effects are stunning.  The camera work isn't slick like on most other Sci-Fi shows, but gritty and realistic.  You feel almost like you're actually there.   <br /> <br />The mixing of cultures - particularly American and Chinese - is disconcerting at first, but only adds to the richness of the Firefly universe.  The fact that there are no aliens makes this show very very different from most Sci-Fi - and Firefly doesn't need aliens to make the universe interesting. <br /> <br />The show is called Firefly because the ship the crew lives on, Serenity, is Firefly class.  They travel from world to world, taking on illegal and, when they have no alternative, legitimate jobs.  The Captain, Mal Reynolds, dwells firmly in the gray areas of life, a disappointed, sarcastic leader who'll stab an unarmed opponent but return stolen medical supplies to a sick community.  He doesn't let a gunshot wound slow him down, but he's also sure to whine about the pain.  He fought as a browncoat, a rebel, in a war against the corrupt government, and lost; the show takes place six years later. <br /> <br />His second in command is Zoe, a stoic, intelligent woman who fought with Mal against the Alliance.  She has a dry wit and tends to be rather more sensible than Mal, though she is completely loyal.  She's married tothe pilot, Wash, who is unbelievably funny, if not exactly an experienced fighter.  It's clear from the outset that Zoe and Wash care deeply for each other, even if they do have some vicious marital spats (Wash's jealousy of Zoe and Mal's relationship and history; Zoe's wish to have a child while Wash prevaricates). <br /> <br />Inara is a registered Companion - basically, a high-class courtesan who gets to choose her own jobs.  Mal takes issue with her choice of career, and there are some definite UST vibes between the two of them.  Inara's the respectable member of the ship, oddly enough, and due to her status can get the crew places that would otherwise have been off limits to them.  The other respectable member of the crew - though he starts out just as a passenger - is Shepherd Book, the futuristic equivalent of a preacher.  He believes very strongly in God, but also has a great deal of knowledge in matters not exactly pertaining to religion, as well as a mysterious connection to the Alliance. <br /> <br />Jayne is the burly, surly mercenary, with changeable loyalties and, frankly, a brain the size of a walnut.  He's crude, shortsighted, and an all-around scumbag - and so hysterically (and often unintentionally)funny that you'll forgive him his faults easily. <br /> <br />Kaylee is the engineer, a young woman with a permanently bright outlook and smile.  She has an expert touch with machinery and a close bond with the ship.  Kaylee is youthful and inexperienced when it comes to theft and firefights, and she freezes during battle and nearly gets herself killed.  Although very pretty and a great flirt, the one guy she's really interested in - Simon Tam - is inept and reserved enough that the relationship never quite manages to get off the ground. <br /> <br />Simon and his teenaged sister River are fugitives from the Alliance.  Simon gave up his life as a successful doctor and rescued River from an Alliance academy, where she was being torured and experimented on.  As a result, she's very unbalanced, though highly intelligent - and she has a way of knowing things she shouldn't be able to know. <br /> <br />The crew isn't exactly one big happy family - Jayne, for instance, is universally distrusted, and River creeps everyone out - but the interplay between the characters is endlessly fascinating and amusing - and sometimes heartbreaking. <br /> <br />Villains range from small-time petty crooks to the government itself - at times, even members of the Serenity crew serve as the villain.  The scariest bad guys are the Reavers, who we never actually see, and the Hands of Blue guys, who are hunting down River. <br /> <br />The plots are intricate and draw the viewer in, and the dialogue is either hysterical or touching or both.  Firefly has both wit and heart, and it's very easy to fall in love with the characters and the stories themselves. <br /> <br />I suppose I should mention the Western feel of the show, as well, though I honestly don't see why so many people make such a big deal out of it.  The incorrect grammar and country twang can be off-putting at first, but I got used to it quickly and didn't really notice it after a while.  As for the planets full of Western-like characters...well, it makes sense to me.  Some planets are rich, and those have all the Sci-Fi tech you could want.  Some are poor, and the people there have to rely on livestock and farming to support themselves.  It's just another way of showing how the rich get richer and the poor get poorer, only this time it's spread out over a number of planets, instead of just the one.
037571457X|5.0|This is a terrific book, and as all the other reviews heap praise on it as well, I'll just leave it at that--except to point out that this is one of those \\"comic books\\" that can be enjoyed even by people who would normally never read a comic book. I've lent it out to several friends now, all of them university English profs like myself. As a reader of a fair number of comics (mostly alternative, non-superhero titles like this one), it's nice to be able to share the joys of this unique medium with people who would normally think it beneath them.
B000E1155E|5.0|Holding the United Kingdom's record for the largest first week sales of a debut album and the distinction of \\"Best New Band\\" and \\"Best British Band\\" in the 2006 NME Awards, the Arctic Monkeys's debut album, Whatever People Say I Am, That's What I'm Not seems to be a safe bet for one of 2006's best. Yet, is it worth all of the hype? With its high energy, extrospective lyrics and attitude, it is a remarkable debut, but quite short of life changing.<br /><br />The album opens with the hollow riff-heavy song, \\"View From The Afternoon,\\" that, despite its shallowness, forshadows the raw fun to ensue. The album continues with their number one single, \\"I Bet You Look Good on the Dance Floor.\\" The track's influences range from The Streets to the The Libertines and mantains the energetic precedent of their predecessors. The Monkeys' social commentary continues with the excellent \\"Fake Tales of San Francisco.\\"<br /><br />One qualm of this album is the length. With thirteen tracks stuffed into forty-one minutes, the energy of this band is blink and miss it with some songs, such as \\"Dancing Shoes\\" and \\"You Probably Couldn't See...\\"<br /><br />By the time you get to \\"Still Take You Home,\\" you realize that the Arctic Monkeys have little technique with a spontaneous sound, reminiscent of The Hives, that is quite effective.<br /><br />Where the Arctic Monkeys best their jaded contemporaries, such as the similar The Walkmen is their evocative social commentary on their peers, such as \\"Riot Van,\\" one the album's best songs with its mellow undertone and the lyrical story it paints.<br /><br />Then the backlash comes. You hear \\"Red Light Indicates Doors Are Secured.\\" You hear \\"Mardy Bum.\\" You hear \\"Perhaps Vampires Is a Bit Strung But...\\" And you realize its the same old show again. These songs, however, prove that it is a show worth hearing.<br /><br />\\"When The Sun Goes Down\\" is a bit of a bore, but the album picks up with the final two tracks \\"From The Ritz To The Rubble\\" and \\"A Certain Romance.\\"<br /><br />While the album is far from as revolutionary and life-changing as The Strokes debut album, Is This It?, the Arctic Monkeys deserve much of the praise it recieves. Their energy. Their lyrics. And their overall talent sets this promising band apart from their peers.<br /><br />Grade : A- (92)<br /><br />Download : Arctic Monkeys - Riot Van, Arctic Monkeys - I Bet You Look Good On The Dance Floor, Arctic Monkeys - Fake Tales of San Francisco, Arctic Monkeys - From the Ritz to the Rubble<br /><br />Skip It : Arctic Monkeys - View From The Afternoonand \\"A Certain Romance.\\" <br /> <br />While the album is far from as revolutionary and life-changing as The Strokes debut album, Is This It?, the Arctic Monkeys deserve much of the praise it recieves. Their energy. Their lyrics. And their overall talent sets this promising band apart from their peers. <br /> <br />Grade : A- (92) <br /> <br />Download : Arctic Monkeys - Riot Van, Arctic Monkeys - I Bet You Look Good On The Dance Floor, Arctic Monkeys - Fake Tales of San Francisco, Arctic Monkeys - From the Ritz to the Rubble <br /> <br />Skip It : Arctic Monkeys - View From The Afternoon

B000BYA5GO|3.0|Just a warning to those purchasing this DVD. Inexplicably, Lions Gate has reformatted this film from its original 2.40:1 aspect ratio to a 1.78:1 ratio. This means the film has been pseudo pan-and-scanned to entirely fill a widescreen TV, just as a full screen version fills a standard TV.  However, new shipments of the DVD are being sent out with a sticker over the original packaging listing the aspect ratio as 2.40:1; presumably, Lions Gate has realized their mistake and shipped out corrected discs.  When purchasing this product from Amazon, I would recommend either waiting a few weeks to ensure Amazon has the corrected discs, or I would check the back of the DVD case before removing the shrink wrap once the DVD has arrived. If the sticker is on the lower-left corner of the back of the DVD stating \\"Aspect Ratio 2.40:1,\\" then it is one of the corrected discs. If, however, there is no sticker and the packaging states \\"Aspect Ratio 1.78:1,\\" then I would ship the DVD back to Amazon and request a replacement with the corrected aspect ratio.  No word yet as to whether or not Lions Gate will be offering a disc replacement program for those who purchased the 1.78:1 version, but hopefully they will offer one soon. In the meantime, make sure you check the package to make sure what you are buying is, in fact, the correct version of the film, as it was intended to be seen.
B00000K0DT|5.0|Nothing is quite  as it   appears in this remarkable gem from director Bryan Singer. Dealing with criminals on a regular basis as I do (as a lawyer, not as one of them), I can assure you that the characters in this movie speak  just like the real thing.  Those viewers who claim that the ending made them feel as if they  had been cheated have no serendipity.  What the ending actually does is provide endless hours of additional enjoyment as you retrace the movie's steps and ultimately realize that, yes, it all made perfect sense;  you just had no idea until you went back and put it all together. B000B0WO0I|4.0|I AM A SIMPLY RED watcher since 1985 when I was 18 years old. I'm 39 now and has not neglected getting the artists' releases including the five DVDs. But I'm no blind follower. For me, the best Simply Red songs are their original compositions, the execrable ones are the covers especially those reggae and soul covers. Practically everytime Hucknall chooses a cover it isn't pleasant to my ears, the only exception would be YOU MAKE ME FEEL BRAND NEW which has not been covered by any other artist before, especially not by a white man. The strongest album remains A NEW FLAME, its very nostalgic for me for it came off when I was concluding my college. Mick's co-writing partnership with LAMONT DOZIER (of Motown fame) for two of A NEW FLAME's songs came out truly superb, true classics. SIMPLIFIED is alright, but not a revelation. But the best reason for owning it is the song SMILE. Its a certified masterpiece, one of the finest Hucknall has written along with SAY YOU LOVE ME. Why does practically everyone in here goes agog with STARS when its the most commercial-sounding and crappy album the band has done? How come not one has commended SMILE's presence in this new album when it could even qualify as the year's loveliest ballad in all pop music genre? How it was performed in the CUBA DVD makes the hefty $27. price worth it. That Hucknall chooses to perform in God-forsaken Cuba may not be for the vanity to make a \\"concert venue breakthrough\\" - penetrating a tyrant-ruled nation which is closed for 60 years. He may have been enticed by Cuba's dilapidated charm (much like he was when he stumbled upon Sicily). Cuba looks like frozen in the 1950s, and most old districts around the city looks uncannily like our own Intramuros and Chinatown districts in old fortressed Manila. Hence, if you're a Simply admirer its imperative toget this one, you may not bother with Stars, unless you're just a completer. Thank you listening.
